summary:
As a dedicated, results-oriented public health worker with international experience, I work constructively in the positive transformation of communities from the grassroots level to the national policy level. I specialise in sexual and reproductive health programming, organisational leadership and transformation, digital media for social change and programme management for non-governmental organisations, leading multiple teams across the African continent (Ethiopia, Uganda, Nigeria, Rwanda, Kenya, Malawi, South Africa and Zimbabwe), working with donor agencies in Germany, and more recently leading global teams from the Netherlands. 

My professional background began in health care management in Zimbabwe. My areas of expertise and focus have been project management for primary health care and sexual and reproductive health and rights, resource mobilisation in crisis contexts, public health surveillance, treatment and prevention mechanisms for communicable diseases; and feminist movement-building for vulnerable groups where grassroots communities are not only recipients of aid and services, but also become agents of change within their localities.  

More recently I have widened my scope to work through public health communication and digital media, and movement-building in hostile contexts on issues such as gender-based violence, structural violence, extractives and the climate crisis, with special emphasis on community empowerment of young people, LGBTI community members, rural and indigenous groups and environmental and human rights activists. 

In my work, I always place special emphasis on equal opportunities for people on the margins, and I believe that my down to earth, practical approach is a proven asset to the many challenges faced in fragile and resource constrained environments.

treasury_media.description: A conversation on the importance of a decolonised, Afro-centric approach to digital data that amplifies the voices of young people to influence national and international policy spaces beyond the paternalistic lens of policy-makers. The political impact of social media is a revolution being led by young people and it is important to ensure that their needs are understood and taken seriously to contribute to meaningful change in previously inaccessible environments.

profile_positions.description: As deputy to the Regional Director, my roles and responsibilities included the management of the JASS Southern Africa team’s annual strategic plan in South Africa, Malawi and Zimbabwe and budget linked to JASS' global annual planning process, including facilitating the co-development of country and regional-specific plans in line with an overarching strategy and priorities. It also entailed having an oversight of the day to day management of JASS Southern Africa’s feminist movement-building work, including ensuring the fulfilment of  work as articulated in donor plans and goals, ensuring obligations and deadlines were met, facilitating regular communication and coordination within the team and with relevant partners as necessary, supporting country coordinators, and facilitating programme - finance crossovers. My tasks also included ensuring the team’s timely submission of quality narrative and financial donor reports and deliverables to regional and country level donors and input on reports to global and core donors. This included tracking deadlines, drafting, editing and reviewing financial reports, and facilitating regular outreach with existing donors. Additionally, I undertook the monitoring, evaluation and learning activities which encompassed engagement and input into the cross-regional MEL team, and ensuring that JASS Southern Africa activities, reflections and learnings were captured using agreed MEL tools and tracking and reporting our impact to donors. Finally, it was my great pleasure to coordinate the JASS Southern Africa Communications and Knowledge products to ensure that there was integration between activity plans, public-facing communication and knowledge creation.

profile_positions.description: Building and supporting communities of empowered young people who own their rights and sexuality is a key element of my work as Regional Manager Africa for RNW Media. By managing teams in Nigeria, Kenya, Uganda and Rwanda, I am able to help ensure that our sexual and reproductive health and rights platform Love Matters Africa reaches young people in anglophone Africa and speaks to their needs. Love Matters Africa prides itself on working with young people to ensure that their voice is heard and their reproductive health and rights needs are catered to through referrals to services providers and access to online counsellors who speak in their language and are made up of SRHR specialists from their own age group. Love Matters Africa is an inclusive, comprehensive, scientifically sound platform that reaches across social, institutional and traditional barriers and gatekeepers to build a community of young people who own their rights and sexual agency.
profile_positions.title: Regional Manager Africa

profile_positions.description: As the Rights, Evidence and Action (REA) Programme Coordinator for RNW Media I worked with a multi-disciplinary team of SRHR and digital media professionals to bring pleasure-positive,  contextualized,  research and evidence-based information to young people on sexual and reproductive health on the African continent and in India. RNW Media is a Netherlands-based NGO for social change that works globally to ensure that young people speak freely about important issues that affect them. The REA programme under Amplify Change focuses on reaching young people via digital media using platforms such as Love Matters to talk to young people about love, sex, and relationships from a pleasure-friendly perspective. This is an online-based project, so young people can access all the information they need from their phones, without having to engage with a third party. The REA programme also strengthens local organisations working with young people in various countries such as Uganda, Kenya, Nigeria and India to improve their online presence and better reach their target communities with messages that are up-to-date, accurate and accessible. As the REA Programme Coordinator my role is to lead these various country teams in their work to engage young people to claim their sexual and reproductive health rights and empower their LGBTI communities.

profile_positions.description: Programmes Manager for eight programmes serving key populations for the Sexual Rights Centre based in Bulawayo, with a coverage throughout Matabeleland North and South. This includes sexual and reproductive health and rights, access to health care, human rights, legal support services and advocacy for marginalised groups, ranging from LGBTI  communities to sex workers, prisoners, women and those who are physically challenged. Programmes include grant management for Amplify Change, Population Services International (PSI), Bridging the Gaps, COC Nederland, Aids Fonds, Open Society Initiative for Southern Africa (OSISA), Oxfam and the Norwegian Students' and Academics' International Assistance Fund (SAIH).

profile_positions.description: Director of 2 large hospitals, 2 schools of nursing and 3 clinics covering rural Matabeleland North and South with a total catchment population of approximately 4 million ensuring the smooth running of primary health care institutions in rural Zimbabwe. Responsibilities included resource mobilisation in order to maintain health care services, international project management, and collaboration with both local and overseas donors in the fight against HIV/AIDS, Malaria and other diseases of poverty. As director responsibilities also included the selection, recruitment and support of medical practitioners locally as well as internationally.
profile_positions.title: Director of Diocesan Health Services

profile_positions.description: This position largely entailed on the ground project implementation and monitoring. This encompassed field work, including the successful distribution of UNICEF medication during the 2009 cholera crisis; as well as the facilitation of communication among Catholic mission hospitals and clinics, and with other health institutions in the country. Responsibilities included assisting senior resident staff at the hospitals and clinics with correct project implementation and recording. Additional tasks were the training of hospital staff on project management and accountability as well as organising inter-provincial meetings between health care stakeholders. The collection, tabulation and storage of health related data into a system database was also important to this position.
